title: fidelma-cook-next-time-anyone-asks-sideways-tilt-head-answer---managing-decline
story: Wersquod all have to take a turn as Pat ie patroller driven around the city until the early hours, calling in at police stations and hospital portersrsquo cubby holes wearily askinganything were happening.There the gruesome, the tragic and sometimes the surreally comic, tales of the city at night were held up as pickings for early hours copy to be inserted into the latest issue.The guys had to be careful, though, when introducing themselves to the punters as the much-beloved Pat Roller, after one became a night incident himself when floored by a drunk who said: lsquoNah, yoursquore no. I met him last week.rsquoIn Ian Rankinrsquos Rebus, I remembered a dozen long forgotten names, and faces flashed through my mind from those days when we shared a strange, interdependent camaraderiehellipand often pub.We fed off each other in wary black humoured jostling and eked out, or fed, bits of information which gave us page leads and splashes, carefully hiding the identities of the lsquocontactsrsquo who supplied them.Our over-inflated expenses ndash mainly drink ndash simply said lsquoentertaining contactsrsquo and no-one would ever dream of asking for a name.Only once was I caught out when working for the notoriously stingy BBC Scotland which demanded namesreceipts were over a certain amount.So, as I had indeed seen a certain Councillor and ed with a good story, I had no qualms about offering a hefty cocktail bar bill from the same day. He and I had had coffee earlier.Called in by an old newspaper hand and now the core of the news gathering operation at the Beeb, George Sinclair, I was not asked to sit as he waved my receipt in front of me.lsquoBit hefty,rsquo he said.lsquoI know,rsquo I said with a grimace. lsquoBut he was swallowing doubles like there was no tomorrow. And I got a great story.rsquoGeorge gave me the death stare ndash I ed it what all the innocence I was good at mustering then.lsquoStrange that,rsquo he said grimly. lsquoHersquos an alcoholic but he went on the wagon six months ago and has been doing great.rsquoI swear I didnrsquot falter as I switched to a pitul expression. lsquoOh, poor, poor man. Well, hersquos well and truly fallen off it now. I pray hersquos not on a bender.rsquoGeorge signed off my expenses. A long time later he told me hersquod been so impressed by my quick-thinking cheek he could do nothing .Anyway Rebus. Not really being a fan of that genre but well aware of its popularity, I ordered the book simply because I read an interview with Ian Rankin where he said hersquod given the now-retired, once hard-drinking, heavy smoker Rebus COPD ndash chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.There wasnrsquot, sadly, much to console or inform me in Rebusrsquo dealings with it, beyond his inhaler use. I am obviously, at Stage , far further down the well than he.But there was one revelatory moment when discussing it with a former colleague, dying from cancer, the term: lsquomanaged decline lsquowas wryly used.And those two words, dear readers, will be my buzz words for  in the absence of the resolutions I never make for fear of tempting the fates. Arenrsquot we all, after all, merely managing decline for most of our lives The ones pounding or cycling the city streets in lycra may race all they like in a bid to keep at peak performance. The sweating gym, carb-limited, supplement-boosting, turmeric-swallowing, smoothie-juicers, may glow all they can to hone and tone those still perfect bodies.You may choose to do pilates, hot yoga, cool meditation, fasting retreats in the Austrian mountains where white clad lsquoexpertsrsquo eat your thousands as you fast and chew each meagre allowed mouthful forty times.You may book mark each, daily, major new story that shows yet another way to stave off cancer or dementia, the bogey-men fears of this century.And as you mash your avocados with chillies and cream your hand-rolled, organic oats with almond milk, you will feel in control and you will feel that just one step ahead of yourhellip.fate.But all the blessed Rankin has now shown me, as the footsteps have barely muddied this pristine year, is that you and me are merely managing decline.I declined some years ago and Irsquom sure Irsquom way, way ahead of many of you, but, for now anyway, I feel quite energised to manage the rest of it.So ndash back to the treadmill the diaphragm breathing exercises, the daily ltrs of water etc etc and out of the slough of despondency.And next time anyone asks, with that sideways tilt of the head and sweet smile, lsquoHow are you rsquo I shall answer ndash managing decline.Just like you but in a slightly dferent way. Upwards and onwards.

title: scots-communities-go-nordic-rising-demands-flags
story: There are now  registered regional, town or city flags in Scotland with eight of those sanctioned in the past three years alone - with five designed to recognise Nordic connections.And now a further four islands are wanting in on the act and are in the process of wanting to impose their status with their own internationally recognised emblem - Skye, Eriskay, Benbecula and North Uist.Philip Tibbetts, community vexillologist. for the Flag Institute, the charity that maintains and manages the registry believes the appetite for such community symbols has stemmed from Scotlands great tradition of sub-national identity as revealed through tartans and names."This tradition is so great that the very richness of identity within Scotland has become a defining part of Scottish identity. The desire for a county, island or regional flag is part of this," he said."As to why this is taking off now I think it is due to communities seeing the popular success of other such flags. This explains why after Shetland became the first [regional flag in ] the momentum has been building. First with neighbouring Orkney and Caithness, then for communities across Scotland."Shetlands was designed in  to commemorate the th anniversary of the transfer of Shetland from Norway to Scotland. The colours were inspired by Scotlands national flag, and the cross shape is from Scandinavian tradition.According to the registry the first town or city flag arrived in Edinburgh. Auld Reekies city flag with its castle and colours of white, black, red dates back to .A competition to design a flag for Skye has attracted  entries, with shortlisting due to take place in January ahead of a public vote. The final design will be revealed in March.Highland councillor John Finlayson from Skye said the attraction of having its own flag, was not just about identity. "Skye as you know has a unique history, culture and heritage which is becoming increasingly well known because of the huge rise in tourism," he said."I am often asked by visitors from overseasSkye has a flag and I have often thought that it would be a good idea to have one to further consolidate our identity and our distinctive place in Scottish history as well as our growing popularity as an international tourist destination."This is why I have been actively involved in the process to host a competition to create a Skye Flag. I also think it would add to the Skye brand and further develop our sense of identity. "Ultimate approval of any flag design lies with the Lyon Court, which exists to grand and record arms for those that want them. The Right Honourable the Lord Lyon King of Arms, the head of Lyon Court, is the Scottish official with responsibility for regulating heraldry in the country, issuing new grants of arms, and serving as the judge of the Court of the Lord Lyon, the oldest heraldic court in the world that is still in daily operation."The general principle would be that Scots can have arms  banners in principle,"said Mr Tibbetts. "This is borne out historically as former Lord Lyon Sir Thomas Innes [who served from  to ] noted, that the general uptake of heraldry in Scotland is historically far higher per capita than in England."Orkney became the third Scottish community to have its own flag, receiving official recognition in April, .It was designed by postman Duncan Tullock, who sketched out his initial idea using his young grandchildrens crayons.Mr Tullocks blue, yellow and red design was voted the best of  designs submitted to the islands council.It replaced an older flag, the red and yellow cross of St Magnus which was considered to be too similar to other national banners.It would take another nine years before a fourth Scottish community flag was approved, leading to a new wave of interest in having a recognised emblem.Mr Tibbetts said: "For a community a flag firstly provides a simple symbol that locals can connect with together. Secondly it can then be used to raise the visibility of that community externally."It is also important nationally as this reinforces the Scottish tradition of having a rich array of symbolism across the nation as seen in tartans and heraldry."Caithness kickstarted the latest appetite for new Scottish heraldry, unfurling their flag in January, .It features a Nordic cross and galley symbolising Caithness ancient ties to the Vikings.The Caithness flag flies next to the Saltire in Wick MarinaThe design was picked from suggestions sent to Highland Council from all over the world.Six months later there was one in Kirkcudbrightshire and then a flag in Denny and Dunipace in Stirlingshire.The Kirkcudbrightshire flag was organised to mark the Queens th birthday.The green and white quarters reference the checks that appeared on a former local authoritys coat of arms, and also the checked cloth used historically to count taxes by the Stewards of the Lords of Galloway.It also features a St Cuthberts cross to reference the origin of the name Kirkcudbrightshire as the "shire of the church of Cuthbert".Denny and Dunipaces town flag is a green, white and blue design showing the River Carron separating Dunipace and its -pointed star to the north and Dennyrsquos two-towered castle symbolising the River of Forts to the south.Raising the South Uist flagIn the Western Isles, South Uists Nordic cross in the pattern of Norways flag secured official recognition for its banner in May, .Donnie Steele, a former councillor, championed South Uists flag, organising a petition to gather support for official recognition.:Barra flag officially recognised six months after terror victimrsquos deathAnd by the end of that year Barras green and white Nordic cross, used by residents of the Hebridean island for decades secured official recognition.In June, that year, the flag was draped over the coffin of Barras Eilidh MacLeod, , who was among the victims of the Manchester Arena attack.Tiree unfurled its new official flag in September, last year. Donald Camerons green and gold "Land of Barley" design was chosen after a competition launched earlier that year."A competition allows for hundreds of designs to be in with a shout. By engaging with the community, such as with the school talks on Skye, and including information with the competition pack explaining what makes an effective flag then as many people as possible can be given as good a chance as possible at creating eligible designs and ultimately winning the final public vote," said Mr Tibbetts.Another public vote led to Sutherland beingamong the latest to get official recognition in December, Source: Philip TibbettsThe winning design featuresa Saltire and a Nordic cross. Three other flags were in contention, including one originally selected by a judging  and drew public criticism for its eagle and stars design.The design represents Sutherlands position as the historic mainland frontier between Scotland the Vikings.East Lothian also had a new flag registered in the same month after another competition. The designer, Archie Martin, sadly passed away after submitting his design.

title: rab-mcneil-weird-enough-get-ahead-new-britain
story: But think about it. The Civil Service is an established part of, er, the Establishment, as is the BBC, which is also under attack by the new Tory Government. Like the BBC, itrsquos a British institution once lauded for its professionalism and objectivity but now suspected of being flaky.Free market types resent the jobs for le and cushy pensions. As someone in favour of both, and indeed of most things that are at ldquothe taxpayerrsquos expense, Irsquove defended the Civil Service in the past. But I can do so no longer, partly because I believe the quality of its staff has plummeted and partly because Irsquom currently filling out my tax . In sunnier times, before climate change, entrants to the Civil Service would often be classics graduates ndash my kind of guys that is to say, useless.There were sensible exams to sit and straightforward interviews in which to demonstrate onersquos charm. Then you were in. Today, graduates in gender studies are invited to sit psychometric tests designed by nutters and passed only by people who should be receiving treatment in benign institutions.Thus, todayrsquos Civil Service is full of folk whose main skills are speaking jargon and claiming that theyrsquore Napoleon. Theyrsquore not even Josephines of all trades, as happened in the past. They are simply masters of nothing.It is perhaps, then, no surprise that Downing Street is planning ldquoseismic changes. For example, mandarins will be made to sit periodic exams to ensure that theyrsquore keeping up. Theyrsquoll no longer be moved frequently from department to department either, but will have to become quite good in one particular area.For the awful truth is that our new political masters are insisting on ndash look away nowyoursquore of a sensitive dispostion ndash competence. This is a massive threat to the British way of le.The impetus for this subversion is said to come from Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministerrsquos senior adviser, who believes a permanent Civil Service is ldquoan idea for the history books, and that it promotes people ldquowho focus on being important, not on getting important things done.Rachel Wolf, co-author of the Toriesrsquo election manesto, wrote in The Dailythis week that the revamped Civil Service will answer to yonder public instead of to ldquostakeholders and will run ldquothe most dynamic state in the world. Whether this includes Scotland is a moot point. Our confused constitutional position is mirrored in the Civil Service here, which is ided into a London-answerable Scotland Office staffed by unionist spies and an Edinburgh-answerable Scottish Government bureaucracy staffed by politically correct, psychometrically tested nutters.Back in Downing Street, meanwhile, Mr Cummings has advertised for ldquoweirdos and ldquomisfits to work for him. Theyrsquoll be left-field in a right-wing government. They wonrsquot be ldquoOxbridge humanities graduates.Itrsquos all very unsettling, or invigoratingyou will, and would make for an interesting job interview. Readers experienced in these will have learned quickly that honesty is not the best policy. Alas, a slow learner, it took me ages to realise that I was doing myself no favours in telling potential employers truthfully that I was unreliable, didnrsquot respect authority, and detested working as part of a team almost as much as I hated using my inidual initiative.So, what do you doyou roll up at Number Ten with your Scotvec certicate in Hospitality and Hairdressing under your arm, and Dominic asks: ldquoSo, are you a weirdo  Well, perhaps you could adapt the words of Sir Humphrey Appleby from televisionrsquos Yes, Minister: ldquoAs far as I can see, looking at it by and large, taking one thing with another, in the final analysis it is probably true to say, that at the end of the day, in general terms, you would probably find that, not to put too fine a point on it, I cannot confirm one way or another at this present juncture that I am, or indeed am not, a nutter.On second thoughts, it might be best just to say ldquoYes, Prime Ministerrsquos senior adviser, and leave it at that.++++STICK your heid in a spool for a minute and Irsquoll rewind you back to the s. Mind you, the winding and rewinding of cassettes was never an exact science so we may have to make a few stops along the way. That was one of the maddening things about cassettes which made us all convert to CDs in the s.But, in , the blasted tapes were back, fuelled by our insatiable quest for nostalgia. Indeed, last week, it was reported that auction sales of punk memorabilia were also going through the roof.Itrsquos not clear whether people are buying cassettes to listen to them or just to look at them while holding a glass of wine and a cigar. And the sales neednrsquot be over-hyped. According to the British Phonographic Industry , , cassettes were purchased last year. That compares to  million in .But, still, therersquos something comforting in keeping old technology alive. Itrsquos kinda steam-punk, I guess, and maybe also two fingers to the clinical, squeaky-clean stuff that streams onto our computers today.I remain a CD man myself, distrusting the virtual world of the ether, where everything is nothing.++++DISAPPOINTING figures about drinking at both the BBC and the House of Commons emerged this week, with observers suggesting the inmates of both institutions werenrsquot imbibing enough.In the Commons, a total of pound. million was spent on booze between  and , down from pound. million in -. Not only that but more was spent on beer and lager than on wine and champagne, reflecting the trend whereby politicians of all parties are now trying to pretend theyrsquore working class.No such problem at the bourgeois BBC, HQ of the trendy metropolitan elite, where spending on prosecco and other sparkling wine doubled in the year to March , a trend confirming that the controversial institution is now completely dominated by women.That said, the total bill for alcohol was only pound,, which is less than most of us spend on a typical Saturday night out in Glasgow.Itrsquos frankly disturbing to learn that our annual pound. licence fee is not being put to good use by our broadcasters, particularly when it is being squandered on prosecco which, in my experience, has to be drunk by the crate before you even start to cheer up and look for a fight.++++THE headline in The Daily Star said it all: ldquo, idiots in London! You say: ldquoThat sounds like a right under-estimate, ken Well, maybe. But it is the number that made stupid, time-wasting  calls last year. One woman rang up to complain that her chippie had sent her three saveloy and chips, when she had only ordered one.Then there was the man who rang up to ask what the time was, and another fellow who complained that the biscuits hersquod just bought were past their sell-by date.Thus our fellow man. According to the politan Police, many of the , calls were pranks, which is deplorable when it means serious calls canrsquot be taken.I was going to suggest establishing separate dedicated numbers for saveloyand biscuit emergencies, but we already have one for the time and that didnrsquot stop one clot ringing .The number for the time, by the way, remains . Itrsquos said that many young people have never heard of it. But they should try giving it a ring. Irsquove just done so. Itrsquos very educational, eventhe woman never listens to a word you say.Read more: Lets make peace with the animals

title: saving-notorious-occult-house-crawley-one-brick-time
story: of Crawley one brick at a timePortrait of Herald journalist Rohese Devereux Taylor. Photograph by Colin Meltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtarnsHe is said to have carried out experiments with sex, drugs and the occult at the house, which was later bought by a rock guitar legend who was intrigued by its checkered history.The current owners of Boleskin House, once owned by notorious occultist Aleister Crowley, hope to rebuild the gutted mansion after a fire devastated it last July by selling its charred remains.The house, which overlooks Loch Ness, was bought by Keith and Kyra Readdy last summer and two days later it went up in flames they had no insurance.It was built in  as a home for members of the Fraser family, the inspiration for time-travelling saga, Outlander.The building is said to lie on the site of a th-Century church that was destroyed with its congregation locked inside. Crowley bought it from a descendant of the Fraser clan in .After a fire ripped through the remains of the mansion last July ndash the second blaze to gut the property after a  fire ndash the Readdys are hoping to raise enough money to continue with renovations to the pile they hope will one day be open to the public and operated as a guest house and spiritual retreat.The new owners have established a charitable trust, the Boleskine House Foundation, and are selling salvaged stones and bags of remains to help towards the cost of renovations they estimate at around pound,.The pound eBay lot description states: ldquoYou are purchasing one original stone of up to g and one bag of charred remains from the fire on  July, , from Boleskine House.The package comes with a certicate of authenticity, with the promise that all proceeds will be used for the restoration of Boleskine House.A crowdfunding campaign was started last year and has so far generated more than pound, of the pound, target for donations.The couple hope fans of the TV phenomenon penned by Diane Gabaldon and starring Scottish actor Sam Heughan as Jamie Fraser will stump up cash to help with the rebuild.Led Zeppelin founder and guitarist Jimmy Page bought the ldquomost notorious home in the Highlands in the s and owned it for around  years. He was said to have followed in Crowleyrsquos footsteps by practicing black magic on the estate.Crowley bought the B-listed Georgian building when he was just  and lived there until . He boasted to have turned the property into ldquoa centre of black magic, evil and sorcery.He conducted black magic rituals and offered animal sacrices to satan and was said to have taken pleasure in the suffering of local people. One episode involved an employee of the estate getting drunk, after  yearsrsquo abstinence, and attempting to kill his we and children. His lodge keeper suffered the loss of a -year-old daughter, while a year later his -month-old son died.Ill-fortune seemed to continue to haunt Boleskine even after Crowleyrsquos departure. It was reported in  the then owner, Major Edward Grant, shot himself in the room Crowley once used for his satanic rituals.However, Page, who bought the property in , said in a  interview: ldquoStrange things have happened in that house which have nothing to do with Crowley. The bad vibes were already there.The rock legend claimed that the head of an executed man, thought to be Lord Lovat who fought with the English during the  uprising, could be heard rolling around the floor. The house also featured in the Led Zeppelin documentary, The Song Remains The Same.Pagersquos childhood friend, Malcolm Dent, worked as the caretaker for Boleskine before the musician sold up in the s after rarely staying there.He once claimed that ldquocurious events occurred at the house, saying: ldquoDoors would be slamming all night. Yoursquod go into a room and carpets and rugs would be piled up.The property was sold to Annette MacGillivray and her husband who lived there happily for  years before it was acquired in  by Dutch owners.Mrs Readdy told reporters in July that people were calling for the house to be razed, saying it was ldquoa den of iniquity.ldquoWe have read so many lurid details, she said. ldquoIt is an architecturally signicant building no matter who has owned it. Boleskine has such a big draw, whether people are fans of Crowley or rock rsquonrsquo roll.ldquoThe Boleskine estate is a treasure of heritage and history that must be secured for future generations. I believe it can stand as a landmark for culture, research and well-being that all can benefit from.

title: joanna-blythman-fusion-gourmet-edinburgh
story: Fusion Gourmet isnrsquot the first Chinese restaurant Irsquove visited where there doesnrsquot appear to be any heating and where the lighting ndash spotlights, glaring bulbs ndash is uncompromisingly pitiless as it shines down on hard plastic surfaces. It offers about as much physical and emotional comfort as the waiting room in a veterinary surgery.We drape our coats over our shoulders for heat and comfort and try not to be downhearted but we canrsquot shake off the feeling that wersquore sitting in a restless corridor, which in effect we are. The door to the street opens regularly, admitting freezing draughts of air and a steady stream of restaurant delivery couriers. From what we can hear they are not native English speakers, possibly Polish, Lithuanian, Pakistani, Kurdish, a hard-working band of polyglots, all trying to make a living in the gig economy.They file past us in their motorbike gear generating lsquotime is moneyrsquo restlessness as they pick up takeaways. They call out a number and the front of house manageress passes bags of food to them in between answering an unbelievably loud and demanding phone with a ringtone that could double up as an alarm for days when you darenrsquot sleep in.: Little Hoi An, Glasgow. Restaurant review by Ron MackennaIn Fusion Gourmet I see a dystopian vision of the future leless restaurants, traffic clogged with food delivery bikes, lonesome diners who lack the energy or will to leave their homes a breakdown of social dining. I hope this restaurant isnrsquot a parable for where current restaurant trends might eventually take us.At first we wonderthey have forgotten to put any tea in our teapot. It tastes like tepid water, but we can see green leaves in there, and yet even brewing time doesnrsquot make them taste like tea. The menu makes few concessions to non-Chinese with language issues and clunky descriptions making a monkey of our understanding. Prawns with lsquoSea Sedgersquo  Whatrsquos that  At pound. Irsquom not likely to take the risk of finding out. lsquoLamb spine hotpotrsquo. lsquoMashed potato with blueberry saucersquo. How weird is that  lsquoBovine tail Chinese yam souprsquo. lsquoStir-fried pig intestine with peppersrsquo. lsquoBeans with kale borecolersquo. lsquoGriddle cooked beef tendonrsquo. This menu, which runs to multiple pages, makes Google Translate look like a % accurate interpretation service.We start somewhat tamely with pork and Chinese leaves dumplings, ten of them. With their elastic dough wrappers and their mulched centres I become aware of a tongue tingling feeling that I associate with stock cubes, or perhaps itrsquos the delayed chemical taste left by the prawn crackers that has just got to me. Our blaseacute disregard of the pictogram that showed two red chillis next to the description of lsquoclay pot lambrsquo leaves us struggling with an oily terra cotta red soup where, in amongst hand-pulled noodles and glass vermicelli, stringy meat slices are outnumbered by what tastes like a chopping boardrsquos worth of dried red chilli. Our tongues are inflamed before the anaesthesia effect sets in.Other dishes make us work hard for our dinner. I suppose I expected a bit, a lot more, beef on the boney contents of what was otherwise an acceptable soy sauce-rich braise scented with star anise. Seeing the description lsquopan-fried Scottish grey sole with salt and chillirsquo I wasnrsquot prepared for a plate of what seemed to be already filleted fish carcass, head and all, deep fried in batter. The frustrating thing here is that the odd flakes of fish still adhering to bone and cartilage under the batter do taste quite good. But for pound. this plateful represents rotten value for money.A glance round the corner reveals that Fusion Gourmet has the equivalent of a private dining area, dark and relatively intimate, with a round dining table around which a group of Chinese men with the air of business people are sat. I guess they share a tacit code that allows them to translate this laminated directory of badly described and sometimes downright odd confections into something approximating to a satisfying meal.Fusion Gourmet, - Lady Lawson Street, Edinburgh   Food:  Atmosphere:  Service:  Value for money:

title: lip-service-needed-save-scotlands-islands
story: The number of babies born last year at the Western Isles hospital fell to , compared to  just four years before, while  of the  islands of the Outer Hebrides have become officially uninhabited in the last half century.While some areas have reported a boost in tourism, those coming to snap the white sandy beaches and wildle for their social media pages do not settle and off-season, placesto their near deserted form.Calls are now being made for urgent action by the government to help rebuild some of the countrys most remote areas and help bring them back to le.Rhoda Grant, Highlands and Islands Labour MSP, was born in Lewis and said that in order to attract and retain more people to the islands, jobs and housing must be prioritised.She accused the Scottish Government of paying "lip service" to the countrys remote communities without acting on promises to help.Grant explained: "On government policy, they say they want re-population but they are a centralising government."The more you centralise, the more you take good quality jobs out of those areas. Anyone looking for a decent career is going to be forced out, and people are still being forced out now."I was born in Lewis and brought up in Wester Ross, thats a case in point. My mother told me I had to leave andI wanted to come back I would be wasting her time and mine because there was no future for me there."She said There is nothing youll do that will build a future and you need to go for your own sake."Who wouldnt choose to live in those beautul places  Butthere is no future for you, government has to create opportunities or nobody will go.""It just appears to me that there is a lot of lip service but no action to do anything concrete."A report published in  showed Uist was bucking the trend, with a rise in younger people moving to the island to raise their families.The number of the registered births on the island for ,  and  increased by  per cent, compared to the decade before and in December  alone there were  babies born - compared to just  for the whole of .Despite the upswing here, official projections for other island communities are less positive, with a  per cent decline predicted for rural Lewis and Harris populations by . Barra is also estimated to see a  per cent decline in its population by then too.Along with good job opportunities, Grant said, there had to be investment in affordable housing, and sustainable transport methods.The MSP said: "There is an issue about housing. In some areas you have people buying a second home and it is totally outbidding locals. There are huge problems with that in Skye and parts of Harris where second homes and Airbnb are the majority of the houses. title: leap-lovers-top-salmon-fishing-hotel-seeks-new-management-duo
story: But it could become a full-time reality for one lucky couple as a hotel on one of Scotlandrsquos most popular salmon fishing rivers goes in search of a new management duo.The opportunity to run the Oykel Bridge Hotel in Sutherland is a rare one. Current manager Neen Mackay has been in the role for three years and although she wants to stay, the lure of home is proving irresistible.Mackay, a former journalist and TV presenter, sacriced quality time with her husband Donnie to take up the job while Donnie remained back home on Lewis. Now she is hoping to find a couple ready for the challenge of running the hotel in time for the new fishing season in March, so she canto the Western Isles.She said: ldquoI absolutely love this job andI was single Irsquod do it for ever, but I think now its time for me to go back home.ldquoItrsquos a great job, but it can also be the loneliest of jobs.ldquoMy husband stayed in Lewis ndash he runs a fishing and shooting lodge so wersquore both involved in the same kind of work. I donrsquot want to leave but I feel obliged to come home for him.The hotel, which is run by a board of directors, caters mainly to those who come to fish on the River Oykel ndash one of the countryrsquos most popular salmon fishing spots.It is so popular, in fact, that it is practically impossible to get a licence to fish there, unless one of the current licence-holders dies.Between March and September, men and women come from all over the world to stay at the hotel, with Mackay explaining it is like ldquoa home from home.She said: ldquoThe vacancy is going to be dficult to fill as you need to have great cooking skills, good meet-and-greet skills, and have to accommodate the clients there who are coming and keep in mind itrsquos a home from home, not just a hotel.ldquoItrsquos % ing customers mostly, fishing people. We occasionally have people coming from the street looking for a bed ndash they are maybe doing the North Coast  or the Cape Wrath Trail.ldquoWe get quite a lot of famous people coming, and wealthy people who have been coming for  to  years.ldquoThis could either make or break two people on their own. Donnie and I have done couplersquos jobs before, we get on incredibly well and thatrsquos fine, but you have to be able to tolerate each other and work with each other  .ldquoItrsquos a huge ask of any couple, for a full seven months of the year.Mackay explained that although she has thrived on the isolation, it may be too much to handle for some people.She said: ldquoYour nearest neighbour on the main road is probably about three miles away, and there are some days you might not see anybody.ldquoFor me I was fine ndash I loved being on my own and I love the area, and the work. I thinkI could I would stay here for ever but I donrsquot think my husband would want to, and le is too short for spending time apart like that,ldquoFor whoever comes, they will need to have a really strong relationship to be able to deal with working and living together  .ldquoIs it ideal for a couple to come along who have a child  Therersquos a fabulous primary school in Rosehall but thenyoursquore looking for activities for them to do, thatrsquos maybe  miles away.ldquoThe countryside is a wonderful place to bring up a child, but you have to think aboutthere is enough to stimulate them without them sitting in front of the television all day.ldquoItrsquos a huge ask of any couple, for a full seven months of the year, but it is a fantastic opportunity for the right people.

title: tv-drama-masks-reality-plunging-island-birth-rate
story: IT is a smash hit show that is expected to trigger a tourist boom to the Outer Hebrides.But the plot of the Christmas special of Call The Midwe could not be further from the truth as the islands are suffering from record low births with population forecasts the worstin Scotland.In the BBC special, Mother Mildred, played by Miriam Margolyes, declares that God is calling her to set up a branch house in the Outer Hebrides to help the islanders, where there is a nurse and doctor shortage struggling to deal with several expectant mothers.However, the reality of being overrun by Hebridean babies is very dferent to the TV show.According to the latest National Records of Scotlandreport there were  births registered in the isles in ,  in  and just  in . Last year, the total is expected to fall below  for the first time in records that go back to , when there were  births.In fact, the last time there were  births was one-quarter of a century ago and the general trend has been steadily downwards ever since.Scotland is facing a fertility crisis ndash the spring birth rate fell to its lowest level since records began, according to the most recent figures.Provisional statistics show , births were registered in the second quarter of  ndash .% lower than . It is the lowest number recorded between April and June since registration began in .Scotlandrsquos population stands at. million, the highest it has ever been, but the Scottish Government has said it faces ldquodistinct challenges.The NRS report said possible reasons for the decline included women leaving motherhood until later in le, women having fewer children and economic uncertainty, ldquoparticularly given that the beginning of the recent fall coincided with the financial crash a decade ago.However, the situation facing the Western Isles is far graver, because they have both a declining and ageing population, which now stands at ,, and increasing numbers of young people leaving. The  population figure was ,.Even between the last two General Elections the electorate had shrunkby around .Western Isles MP Angus MacNeil said retaining young people ndash andthe lack of births ndash in the isles wasa real problem.ldquoWe are facing dficult issues over depopulation and there is no single magic bullet, but the solution revolves around affordable housing, jobs and the transfer of political powers that can make a real dference. I look to the Faroes a few hundred miles away and see how their population is booming and ours is not. There are vital lessons to be learned there, he said.Scotlandrsquos first National Islands Plan was officially launched last month.Reversing the plunging population levels on the islands will be the key to their long-term survival, according to the blueprint to safeguard their future.Some islanders feel their communities are at risk as youngsters leave to seek opportunities on the mainland, the plan admits.The document has been hailed as a ldquohistoric milestone by the Scottish Government and seeks to address concerns about economic growth, transport and connectivity.There are  inhabited islands off Scotlandrsquos north and west coasts which contribute to the countryrsquos ldquonational identity, according to the blueprint.ldquoOver the last  years, almost twice as many islands have lost populations as have gained, the plan warns.Projections suggest Orkney and Shetland face losing .% of their population by  and the Western Isles %. The equivalent figure for Scotland over the same time period is an increase of .%.The Outer Hebrides are expected to see a % decline in children and % of working age people over the same period. Over the last few years schools have been shut and merged as theyran out of enough youngsters to make them viable.Islands Minister Paul Wheelhouse said: ldquoThe plan is a key milestone but it cannot be allowed to just sit on a shelf. title: view-islands-precious-part-history-just-scenery-offer
story: The Scottish Government is researching what needs to be done for island survival. But surely itrsquos obvious  Good job opportunities, not just seasonal tourism, and decent and affordable housing allied to sustainable transport links. There is, too, the perennial issue of land ownership and the large estates which contribute little to local economies.There are successful local examples of recovery, in parts of Colonsay and West Harris where local control of land and marine assets, together with building affordable homes has encouraged young people to remain or . These need to be built upon and, yes, this will require investment from government and,necessary, compulsory purchase powers to ensure that housing and businesses are set up.Our islands are a precious part of our history, but also an essential part of our future. title: Iain Macwhirter  Scottish independence won t be won or lost over finance - Brexit showed that it s not the economy
story: Since itrsquos a new year, let me pay due respect to the prolic statistically-literate Unionist businessman, Kevin Hague. He must be the most patient man alive, almost a social media saint. Watch him calmly respond to vilication and abuse every time he points out that taxes raised in Scotland could not sustain public spending, were Scotland to become independent tomorrow.Scotland has a nominal deficit of several billions of pounds which could cause immediate fiscal belt-tighteningthe Barnett taps were turned off. I say nominal because there is much controversy over Haguersquos figures.However, he won a signicant victory last year when the Scottish Government largely accepted, in the Sustainable Growth Commission, his arguments about Scotlandrsquos fiscal position, based as they are on the GERS calculations of Government spending and revenues.Nicola Sturgeon now accepts that independence will involve short-term spending restraint. Thatrsquos better than long-term decline under Westminster rule, she says. Yoursquod think that this admission would have damaged the SNPrsquos electoral standing, but the reverse is true. Last month they enjoyed another landslide victory.So herersquos the puzzle: why have Scottish voters not punished the SNP for agreeing that independence could mean, at the very least, a period of economic dislocation and public spending cuts  The Growth Commission numbers suggest that SNP promises of more cash for the NHS and social care, a costly new benefits system, compensation for Waspi women, electrication of transport and many other spending commitments would be hard to achieve.At the very least taxes would have to rise. But Scottish voters donrsquot seem particularly worried. This is because they are bothered about something more important than deficits. Brexit shows that when it comes to issues of sovereignty and identity, it isnrsquot ldquothe economy, stupid. Rarely has a political axiom been so comprehensively disproved. It clearly isnrsquot the economy that has been driving events in the UK.Looking back over the past three turbulent years, itrsquos obvious that Remainers had the best arguments. If you regard Brexit, as Hague would, as a purely economic exercise in cost-benefit analysis, it stinks. Leaving the largest and wealthiest free trade area on the planet is almost impossible to justy on narrow economic terms.There will almost certainly be a quick and dirty free trade deal negotiated in  that will remove tarfs on goods. But % of UK trade is in non-physical services. There is bound to be an increase in non-tarf barriers to British trade with the single market which will affect UK businesses. That is why so many financial companies have already been setting up shop in Dublin to operate within the rules of the EU single market.Supply chains will be disrupted, which is why car manufacturers were so opposed to Brexit. There have been problems on the high street this Christmas with the shortage of casual labour. The departure of EU citizens is likely to damage education, agriculture manufacturing and services, especially care services.Left-wing Remainers tried to claim that in some way it was billionaires who were behind Brexit, but this was never the case. Remain was, is, a thoroughly pro-capitalist, pro-business case, vigorously pursued and financed by the largest corporate interests, from car manufacturers to banks.Gina Miller is no socialist. Nor is the governor of the Bank of England, the head of Goldman Sachs, or the bosses of Jaguar Land Rover and Honda. It was a handful of pub-chain capitalists, such as Tim Martin of Wetherspoon, who backed Brexit. They are essentially English nationalists who think that Brexit is in some way a declaration of independence.Brexit, as they saw it, was about winning freedom from unelected Brussels bureaucrats and letting Britain stand strong in the world. Irsquod say thatrsquos nonsense, of course. It was never clear that membership of the single market involved a diminution of British sovereignty, even though much trade legislation had been ceded to Brussels. But economic rationality is really not the point.Brexit was essentially an argument about democracy and nationalism. As the General Election has shown, for millions of voters the economy, finance and fiscal policy had very little to do with their political priorities. Remainers were comprehensively defeated because they appeared to do down Britain and ignored the will of the people. Brexit had won the referendum, and no amount of economic reality was going to change votersrsquo minds.The Scottish Government loathes Brexit, and for very good reasons. Scots did not vote to leave the European Union for a start. But in the longer term, Brexit is very good news for the SNP. No matter what arguments unionists such as Hague deploy in future about Scotlandrsquos deficit, it will surely not determine whether or not Scotland leaves the UK.There are three immediate reasons why the Scottish deficit does not, at present, deter people from voting SNP. The Scottish Government has managed the finances of Holyrood reasonably competently over the past decade. There is great scepticism about spending arguments, which voters tend to dismiss as Project Fear.Thirdly, departure from the UK would not happen overnight, and there would be complex financial and trading negotiations before the Union was dissolved.But forget all that, because the urge for freedom trumps any argument over a few billions in tax revenues. Scottish voters know, intuitively, that Scotland is a relatively wealthy country, better off than most regions of England. Labour productivity is comparable to the UK average. Scotland has prodigious natural resources and a highly educated workforce. Scotland has the national income of Portugal and the population of Slovakia.Thatrsquos all they need to know. Indeed, were I advising the SNP, Irsquod say they should stop agonising about currency, fiscal transfers and deficits. What will defeat those arguments is not more numbers, but the emotional appeal to national identity that won Boris Johnson his election victory.Scots did not vote to leave the European Union. They did not vote to lose their EU citizenship, with all the protections that brings. They did not vote to cut EU immigration did not vote to accept trade deals with the United States did not agree to the diminution of environmental standards and did not vote to be subjected to untrammelled Tory rule from Westminster.Thatrsquos really all the SNP need to say. Voters will do the rest.

title: hollywood-actor-brian-cox-calls-second-scottish-independence-referendum
story: The Dundee-born star, currently being lauded for his portrayal of an ageing media magnate in acclaimed TV drama Succession, said his native country has been ldquoignored andldquoenough is enough.During last monthrsquos General Election, the SNP won  of Scotlandrsquos  constituencies.The result led party leaderNicola Sturgeon to call for a second referendum, following rsquos decision for Scotland to remain in the UK.And -year-old Cox, a multi-award winning actor whose film roles include Manhunter, The Bourne Identity and Troy, has now backed those calls.Speaking at the Bafta Tea Party event in Los Angeles, he told the PA news agency: ldquoI would think we need to look at it, I think we need a referendum and see what we think. Wersquove been sidelined for so long and treated really not very well. And not taken very seriously.Cox, who is nominated for a Golden Globe this weekend for his role in Succession, said the Labour party had ldquofailed in Scotland, after it registered just one MP following the last election.The actorleft Labour in  to join the SNP.Cox said Scotlandrsquos pro-Remain vote in the  Brexit referendum, when the country voted % in favour of staying in the EU, was part of the reason Scots are ldquoorganically moving towards a decision to leave the UK.ldquoEventually you can push people so far and theyrsquore finally going to say lsquoenough is enough,rsquo he added.ldquoReally, we need to take care of our own destiny, finally.Askedhe thought Scotland would vote to leavean independence referendum were held tomorrow, he said: ldquoItrsquos hard to say.ldquoThe Scots are very canny and they keep a lot to their chest, Cox added.ldquoSo theyrsquore not necessarily going to give things away. I was very much concerned with the last referendum and I always thought that people slightly underestimated the older generation keeping things to their chest.ldquoNow a lot of that generation is gone and a lot of new young people are coming through, so wersquoll see.Speaking on the state of politics across the UK generally, Cox, said it is ldquoconfusing and ldquochaotic and described himself as ldquovery sad about the UKrsquos impending departure from the EU.Cox has won widespread critical acclaim for playing Logan Roy in HBOrsquos hugely popular Succession and is nominated for the best actor in a TV drama series at Sundayrsquos Golden Globes.Roy is the ruthless patriarch of a media dynasty, leading to comparisons to both the Murdoch family and the Trumps.Cox however, said his portrayal is not based on a real person.ldquoNo, not at all, he said. ldquoI just do the job, learn the lines and donrsquot bump into the furniture.

title: labour-taken-stronger-position-brexit-says-sir-keir-starmer
story: Sir Keir said that people wanted ldquoclarity on the issue, which the Labour Party did not provide, and that not enough was done by the party to ldquoknock down the Toriesrsquo Get Brexit Done message.He added that,he was to become Labourrsquos new leader, he would deliver the ldquofundamental change needed to deal with inequality across the country.Sir Keir said Labour lost the general election due to four main reasons which cumulatively caused the party to ldquolose the publicrsquos trust.Speaking on Skyrsquos Ridge On Sunday, he said: ldquoThe issues, there were many of them, but they were the leadership, rightly or wrongly, fairly or unfairly, was coming up everywhere.ldquoThe Brexit position and whether we were persuading people, more importantly, whether we were knocking down the Tories claim that they would get Brexit done.ldquoAnti-Semitism came up as a question of values and competence, and there was a general feeling that the manesto was overloaded. They were the four main reasons.Sir Keir also outlined what a future Labour government led by him would look like, calling for more long term investment for businesses and the government and private sector to set green targets and requirements together.He added: ldquoI would like to see private schools as an irrelevant because the state sector was so good, and wersquove underfunded the state sector.But Labour shouldnrsquot throw away all of the ideas followed by Jeremy Corbyn, he said.I believe another future is possible ndash but we have to fight for it.Thatrsquos why Irsquom standing to be leader of the Labour Party.Join me and together we can ndash and we will ndash win: https:t.co LQiNItoDU pic hZQaDBmxMmdash Keir StarmerJanuary , ldquoWhat Jeremy Corbyn brought to the Labour Party in  was the start of saying we should be anti-austerity and pro public services. That is right. We donrsquot want to throw that away.ldquoIrsquom not pretending we need to keep everything as it is, Irsquom not pretending there was anything good about that general election result, it was devastating, but we shouldnrsquot retreat from the radicalhellip fundamental change is needed in this country and we must deliver it, he said.Discussing the problems with Labourrsquos Brexit position, Sir Keir added: ldquoI think clarity about what your position is and not being able to say well would you be leave or remain after a general election was a problem and I made that argument but I accepted the decision.ldquoI think people wanted clarity and they wanted leadership.ldquoPeople had bought the idea thatyou vote Tory yoursquoll get Brexit done and we didnrsquot knock it down hard enough.He also said the argument for a second referendum ldquoblew away with the election result and that the conversation must ldquomove on to the framework for future trade relations.ldquoWersquore going to leave the EU in the next few weeks.He added: ldquoIt is inevitable that Boris Johnson and his Government will look to America for a trade deal, and we need to know the terms of that.Pressed on the situation in Iran, Sir Keir accused the Government of ldquoblindly following the Americans and not providing answers on whether President Donald Trumprsquos actions were lawful.ldquoThis is a very serious situation and unquestionably blindly following the Americans is in my view the wrong thing to do.Askedhe would ever support military action, he added: ldquoI would pass legislation that said military action could be takenfirst the lawful case for it was made, secondly there was a viable objective, and thirdly we got the consent of the Commons.ldquoI think that legislation is much needed, he said.
